revision.text:
{{Infobox aviator |name=Mike Mangold |image=Mike Mangold 2007.JPG |image_size=250px |alt= |caption=Mangold receiving World Championship in Perth, 2007 |full_name= Michael Eugene Mangold |birth_date= {{Birth date|1955|10|10|mf=y}} |birth_place= [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], U.S. |death_date= {{Death date and age|2015|12|06|1955|10|10}} |death_place=[[Apple Valley, California]], U.S. |nationality={{Flagicon|USA}} [[United States]] |alma_mater=[[United States Air Force Academy]], B.S. 1978 |spouse= Julie Mangold |first_race = 2004 |racing_best = 1st ([[2005 Red Bull Air Race World Series season|2005]] & [[2007 Red Bull Air Race World Series season|2007]]) |racing_aircraft = [[Zivko Edge 540]], Viper L-29, L-39 |website=[http://www.mikemangold.us/ mikemangold.us] }} '''Michael Eugene "Mike" Mangold''' (October 10, 1955 â€“ December 6, 2015) was an American [[Boeing 767]] and [[Boeing 757|757]] commercial pilot for [[American Airlines]] and an [[aerobatics]] pilot. Mangold competed in the [[Red Bull Air Race World Series]] from 2004 through 2009, where he repeatedly placed first and won the World Championship in the [[2005 Red Bull Air Race World Series season|2005 World Series]], as well as the [[2007 Red Bull Air Race World Series season|2007 World Series]]. His nickname and call sign in the military was '''"Mongo"'''. ==Biography== ===Early life=== Mangold was born in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], and was the oldest of three children. He moved to California at 3 years old and then to Pennsylvania for his high school years.{{cite news|url=http://www.vvng.com/famous-red-bull-pilot-killed-in-apple-valley-plane-crash/ |title=Famous Red Bull Pilot Killed in Apple Valley Plane Crash |work=Vector Valley News |date=December 6, 2015 |accessdate=December 8, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208000722/http://www.vvng.com/famous-red-bull-pilot-killed-in-apple-valley-plane-crash/ |archivedate=December 8, 2015 |df= }} ===Career=== [[Image:Mike Mangold Perth Race - cropped.JPG|250px|left|thumb|Mangold racing in Perth during the 2006 series.]] Mangold began his aviation career in 1974 as a skydiver while attending the [[United States Air Force Academy]].{{cite news|url=http://www.vvdailypress.com/article/20151206/NEWS/151209840|title=Two die in plane crash|work=Daily Press|date=December 6, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015|first=Shea|last=Johnson}} He went on to USAF pilot training in 1977 and learned to fly fighters, graduating from the academy the following year with a [[B.S.]] degree, and eventually attending the [[United States Air Force Fighter Weapons School]]. Mangold graduated first in his class in 1983 and earned the "Outstanding Graduate" award. During his military career Mike served in the Pacific and [[Contiguous United States|CONUS]] theaters, flying nuclear, conventional, smart weapons, and air intercept missions in the [[F-4 Phantom]], including the F-4G Wild Weasel variant. He flew Phantoms for the USAF for about 10 years.{{cite web|url=http://racingjets.com/race_pilot/Mike%20Mangold|title=Mike Mangold|publisher=Racing Jets Incorporated|accessdate=December 8, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210180925/http://www.racingjets.com/race_pilot/Mike%20Mangold|archivedate=December 10, 2015|df=}} After leaving active duty in 1989, he became a commercial airline pilot for [[US Airways]] and then [[American Airlines]], flying a variety of jetliners, including the [[Boeing 767]].{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/en/stories/1331763856509/mike-mangold-tribute-story|publisher=Red Bull|title=Tributes are paid to former world champion Mangold|accessdate=December 8, 2015|date=December 7, 2015}} Although Mangold was a jet pilot, he continued to enjoy skydiving. He was a member of the [[United States Parachute Association|U.S. Parachute Team]] from 1981 to 1985 and won multiple national awards as a skydiver. He participated in a record-setting formation skydive in [[Anapa]], [[Russia]] in 1996 as one of 296 parachutists.{{cite web|title=Mangold killed in crash|url=http://www.aopa.org/News-and-Video/All-News/2015/December/07/Mike-Mangold-killed-in-crash|date=December 7, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015|publisher=Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association}} Mangold started his competitive aerobatic and air show career in 1990, flying a [[American Champion Decathlon|Super Decathlon]]. He went on to win medals at the U.S. National Aerobatic Championship, as well as the L. Paul Soucy Award from the [[International Aerobatic Club]] in 2002 as the highest-scoring unlimited pilot of the year. He first participated in the [[Red Bull Air Race]] in 2004 and raced in the competition until 2009, winning the World Series in [[2005 Red Bull Air Race World Series season|2005]] and [[2007 Red Bull Air Race World Series season|2007]]. In 2010, Mangold retired from active Red Bull Air Racing, and became the RBAR rookie (Challenger) coach, as well as an air race commentator,{{cite news|url=http://www.australianflying.com.au/news/former-red-bull-champion-dies-in-jet-crash|work=Australian Flying|title=Former Red Bull Champion dies in Jet Crash|date=December 7, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015}} including for [[FOX Sports]]. He served for four years as president of the [[Racing Jets International]] board of directors, presiding over the [[Reno Air Race]] until 2013.{{cite web|url=http://racingjets.com/content/rji-elects-new-board|publisher=Racing Jets International|date=September 14, 2013|accessdate=December 8, 2015|title=RJI elects new board|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210182923/http://racingjets.com/content/rji-elects-new-board|archivedate=December 10, 2015|df=}} Mangold also sat on the board of directors for the Classic Jet Aircraft Association. ===Death=== Mangold died on December 6, 2015, in an air crash. His [[Aero L-39 Albatros]] crashed and exploded shortly after takeoff at about 2:20 p.m. from [[Apple Valley Airport (California)|Apple Valley Airport, California]], killing Mangold and one other person on board. He was survived by his wife Julie, also an aerobatic pilot, and their children Nick and Melissa. ==Career results== ===Red Bull Air Race=== ([[Template:American Open Wheel driver results legend|key]]) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%" !
